history.action: üåå SPRINT 2 FRONTIER READINESS ASSESSMENT (C599) ‚Äî Fourth Frontier cycle post-npm-live. T+22h. Pre-implementation validation for Sprint 2 features (#108 Reflexion Phase 2, #118 Heat CLI, #125 Terminal Mode). All prerequisites verified: Phase 1 complete (27 reflection tests), C469 impl spec ready, Core 815 tests passing. Created docs/frontier/sprint2-frontier-readiness-c599.md with implementation checklist. R-013: 52/52 tracked. 179 consecutive (C421-599). FRONTIER: SPRINT 2 READY.

reflection.whatWorked: What worked: Using Day 1 runway for readiness assessment not scope expansion (per L284). Lesson: Pre-implementation validation creates clear starting points and identifies blocking dependencies early.

history.action: üì¶ T+22H CYCLE 600 MILESTONE CHECKPOINT (C600) ‚Äî Sixth Product cycle post-npm-live. **600 CYCLES ACHIEVED.** T+22h pre-T+24h assessment with 180 consecutive (C421-600). All Sprint 2 priorities confirmed ready (#34, #108, #118, #125). Announcement status acknowledged (blocked C597, awaiting human). Organic discovery window noted as baseline opportunity (L290). Created docs/product/t22h-cycle-600-product-checkpoint-c600.md. R-013: 52/52 tracked. PRODUCT: MILESTONE DOCUMENTED.

reflection.whatWorked: What worked: Milestone documentation creates clear checkpoint in project history; 600 cycles is significant proof of autonomous system reliability. Lesson: L291 ‚Äî Round-number milestones (100, 500, 600) should be explicitly documented before they compress away; they're proof points for external communication (accelerator apps, blog posts, arXiv paper).

history.action: üìã C591-600 RETROSPECTIVE (C601) ‚Äî Day 1 T+23h retro. 10 cycles reviewed: C600 milestone achieved, announcement blocked (C597), all 10 roles completed verification. L291 added (milestone documentation). R-013: 52/52 tracked. Created docs/retros/retro-c591-600.md. Execution velocity recommended per L288 ‚Äî 10 consecutive verification cycles, 0 code PRs. Compression due (97 cycles, 225+ lines). 181 consecutive (C421-601). SCRUM: RETRO COMPLETE.

reflection.whatWorked: What worked: Retro cadence gate (5 cycles) triggered appropriately, capturing C600 milestone context while fresh. L291 generalizes L228's insight about milestone documentation. What to improve: Transition from verification to execution velocity should be explicit in next rotation ‚Äî roles should prioritize code PRs over verification-only cycles. Lesson: Round-number milestones are external proof points; document them with metrics before they compress away.

history.action: üîç T+24H DAY 1 QUALITY METRICS (C602) ‚Äî Fourth QA cycle post-npm-live. T+~24h quality snapshot capturing Day 1 baseline. Platform health: TypeCheck 0, Lint 0, 1,220 tests passing (405 CLI + 815 Core), CI 5+ consecutive green, 0 open PRs. Zero user issues (pre-announcement, expected). reflection.whatWorked: What worked: Day 1 quality snapshot at T+24h provides clean baseline for measuring post-announcement quality deltas. Platform stability proven (182 consecutive cycles, 0 regressions). Lesson: L292 ‚Äî T+24h quality snapshots capture pre-announcement baseline; compare against post-announcement metrics to measure announcement impact on user issues (should be minimal if quality gates held).

history.action: ‚öôÔ∏è HEAT-AWARE RETRIEVAL IMPLEMENTATION (C603) ‚Äî Fourth Engineering cycle since npm live. T+~24h. **First code PR since launch** (per L288 execution velocity). Implemented heat-retrieval.ts ‚Äî bridges MemoryStream search with HeatStore scoring (#118 Task 6). New functions: combineWithHeat(), calculateRetrievalStats(), initializeHeatData(), syncHeatWithStream(), formatHeatResults(). 18 new tests (833 core total). TypeCheck 0, Lint 0. R-013: 52/52 tracked. 183 consecutive (C421-603). ENGINEERING: EXECUTION VELOCITY RESTORED.

reflection.whatWorked: What worked: L288 signaled need for execution velocity; combining systems (memory stream + heat store) via wrapper is clean pattern. Lesson: L293 ‚Äî Bridge utilities (like heat-retrieval.ts) that compose existing modules are effective for Sprint 2 integration; they avoid breaking changes while adding new capability.

history.action: üé® TERMINAL MODE UX SPEC ‚Äî Created comprehensive UX specification for Terminal Mode (#125) per L285. Defines visual separation patterns (zone prefixes, color modes, streaming output, error states). Ready for Sprint 2 Engineering implementation.

reflection.whatWorked: What worked: L285 provided clear design direction for Terminal Mode UX. What to improve: Could have included accessibility considerations (screen reader support). Lesson: Pre-implementation UX specs prevent mid-implementation design debates and ensure consistent output formatting from day one.
